Regina Leader-Post http://leaderpost.com Regina Latest News, Breaking Headlines & Sports Sun, 18 Feb 2018 15:49:59 +0000 en hourly 1 http://wordpress.com/ https://postmedialeaderpost2.files.wordpress.com/2017/09/lp-wordmark-250x33.pngRegina Leader-Posthttp://leaderpost.comRegina Latest News, Breaking Headlines & Sports White City's Marsha Hudey finishes 10th in Olympic speed skating http://leaderpost.com/sports/olympics/white-citys-marsha-hudey-finishes-10th-in-olympic-speed-skating http://leaderpost.com/sports/olympics/white-citys-marsha-hudey-finishes-10th-in-olympic-speed-skating#respond Sun, 18 Feb 2018 15:49:50 +0000 http://leaderpost.com/?p=361223 Marsha Hudey competed in the women’s 500-metre speed skating event Sunday morning, finishing 10th.

The White City-born long-track speed skater said she was happy with her result. Fellow Canadian Heather McLean finished 14th in the same event.

Marsha Hudey of Canada competes during the women’s 500 meters speedskating race at the Gangneung Oval at the 2018 Winter Olympics in Gangneung, South Korea, Sunday, Feb. 18, 2018.

 

Marsha Hudey of Canada reacts after her race during the women’s 500m Individual Speed Skating Final on day nine of the PyeongChang 2018 Winter Olympic Games at Gangneung Oval on February 18, 2018 in Gangneung, South Korea.

 

Canada’s Marsha Hudey competes in the women’s 500m speed skating event during the Pyeongchang 2018 Winter Olympic Games at the Gangneung Oval in Gangneung on February 18, 2018.

 

Canada’s Marsha Hudey competes in the women’s 500m speed skating event during the Pyeongchang 2018 Winter Olympic Games at the Gangneung Oval in Gangneung on February 18, 2018.

Related

  • White City's Hudey quickly overcame rough start
]]> http://leaderpost.com/sports/olympics/white-citys-marsha-hudey-finishes-10th-in-olympic-speed-skating/feed/ 0 021818-Pyeongchang_Olympics_Speed_Skating_Women legacycontent Former NHLers turn back the clock in alumni game http://leaderpost.com/sports/hockey/regina-pats/former-nhlers-turn-back-the-clock-in-alumni-game http://leaderpost.com/sports/hockey/regina-pats/former-nhlers-turn-back-the-clock-in-alumni-game#respond Sun, 18 Feb 2018 08:23:07 +0000 http://leaderpost.com/?p=350086 It was just like old times at the Brandt Centre on Saturday.

Well, almost.

The shots were a bit softer and the beards were a little greyer, but the spirit of old-time hockey was alive and well when Team WHL outgunned Team Saskatchewan 12-11 in the All-Star Celebrity Classic.

“I feel like I’m 20 years old again,” offered legendary Regina Pats goaltender Ed Staniowski, 62, who was named Team Sask’s player of the game despite being the oldest player on the ice.

Netminder Ed Staniowski makes an old-school save during the All-Star Celebrity Classic at the Brandt Centre on Saturday.

“So many memories came back. There’s no hitting going on out there — just the beauty of the pass, the beauty of the open ice. These guys are masters. People here in Regina had a chance to see the game how it should be played.”

Almost 45 years have passed since Staniowski backstopped the Pats to their most recent Memorial Cup title. He grew up in an era of firewagon hockey that was easy on the eyes and tough on goalies — not unlike Saturday’s alumni game.

“Fans like to see the goals,” Staniowski said with a smile. “Unfortunately that’s not good for me but, in the end, everybody goes away a winner.”

Team WHL’s lineup included several players who were barely removed from their NHL days, including Eric Brewer, Jarret Stoll, Travis Moen, Robyn Regehr and Colby Armstrong.

Others like Scott Niedermayer, Rob Brown and Geoff Courtnall were still able to flip the switch, looking at times like they had barely lost a step.

Mike Sillinger has a laugh with his teammates at the bench during the All-Star Celebrity Classic at the Brandt Centre on Saturday.

Staniowski limited them to four goals on 18 first-period shots before he took a well-deserved rest on the bench, trailing 4-2. The deficit grew to 9-4 in the second, but Team Sask wouldn’t resort to ill-favoured tactics.

“No (neutral zone) trap!” insisted Pats great Mike Sillinger. “The only guy to dump the puck in was our all-time leading scorer, Dale Derkatch. We had to fine him.”

The strategy almost paid off.

Team Sask suddenly narrowed the gap to 9-8 — thanks to a timely assist from the scoreboard operator. Team WHL didn’t file a formal protest but coach Darryl Sutter hinted to some concerns with the officiating in the third period.

“I’m sure if we could go to video review a lot of those goals wouldn’t count,” he said with a grin.

Undaunted, the WHL all-stars upped their lead 10-8 just 25 seconds into the third on a great rush by 52-year-old Cliff Ronning, who showed the wheels of a player half his age. While celebrating the goal, Ronning was rubbed out along the boards by Stu (Grim Reaper) Grimson, who wanted to settle an old score.

“Cliffy has been tormenting me since he and I were 10, 11, 12 years of age,” Grimson said of his former B.C. minor-hockey rival. “Any time I get an opportunity to give a shot back, I’m happy to do that.”

Dale Derkatch, left, tries to trip up Robyn Regehr during the All-Star Celebrity Classic at the Brandt Centre on Saturday.

Following Grimson’s example, Team Sask was able to find another gear in the third period, eventually taking an 11-10 lead.

However, Team WHL wouldn’t be denied.

Armstrong tied it with five minutes left and Ron Sutter added the winner with 42 seconds on the clock.

“We knew they had a little younger blood,” said Sillinger, 46, who scored once in a losing cause. “It just took our bones a little longer to warm up but it turned out to be a good game. We almost went to overtime but they had a little more firepower than we did.”

Did they ever.

“We pulled our goalie and their final five was Courtnall, both Niedermayer brothers, Eric Brewer and Stoll,” recalled defenceman Jamie Heward, who scored twice. “All five could probably still play in the NHL right now. I’m looking up going, ‘Wait a minute. Something is wrong here.’ ”

The WHL all-stars made no apologies.

They even admitted — sort of — to shortening their bench late in the contest to gain an advantage.

“We had some (old) guys who didn’t want to play in the third so we had to go real short,” quipped Sutter, whose young guns ultimately paid some begrudging respect to their elders.

“(Team Sask) came on in the third period a little bit; they found a little more ‘want’ in their game,” said a chuckling Darcy Tucker, 42, who finished with a goal and two assists. “We had a few younger guys, even though a couple of our younger guys — meaning me — had a new hip. That was my first game back playing hockey this year so it was interesting. I had a lot of fun.”

So did Grimson, who was credited with one assist but zero penalty minutes.

The legendary enforcer didn’t even mind keeping his gloves on.

“I couldn’t fight my way out of a wet paper sack right now,” he said with a laugh. “I wasn’t looking for any takers. I was completely resting on the laurels.”

Fisticuffs aside, the players did their best to pay tribute to a bygone era.

They also had a blast doing it.

Wendel Clark, left, and Jeff Odgers have a laugh during the All-Star Celebrity Classic at the Brandt Centre on Saturday.

“I think we turned back the clock a little bit,” continued Grimson, one of 10 ex-Pats who suited up in the game. Among them was Jock Callander, who will have his No. 15 retired by the team prior to Sunday’s game against the Moose Jaw Warriors (2 p.m., Brandt Centre).

Callander was reunited in the alumni game with former Pats teammates Dale Derkatch and Garth Butcher. They were part of a team in the early ’80s that embodied old-school hockey and is still romanticized for its high-scoring brand.

Based upon Saturday’s throwback performance, those players can still draw a crowd.

“Everyone knows defence wins, but I wish it would go back to the old offensive ways,” Callander said earlier this week. “I think hockey was more fun to watch back then.”

gharder@postmedia.com

]]> http://leaderpost.com/sports/hockey/regina-pats/former-nhlers-turn-back-the-clock-in-alumni-game/feed/ 0 021818-All-Star_Classic_G,_Regina,_17_Feb_2018_(6_of_20) gregharderlp Cougars advance to Canada West semi-final http://leaderpost.com/sports/local-sports/cougars-advance-to-canada-west-semi-final http://leaderpost.com/sports/local-sports/cougars-advance-to-canada-west-semi-final#respond Sun, 18 Feb 2018 04:50:47 +0000 http://leaderpost.com/?p=360936 The University of Regina Cougars are moving along the playoff trail in Canada West women’s basketball.

The University of Regina Cougars women’s basketball team is celebrating a first-round playoff sweep of the UBC Thunderbirds.

The Cougars are to play host to the University of Calgary Dinos in a best-of-three semi-final that is to begin Thursday at the Centre for Kinesiology, Health and Sport. Games are also set for Friday and, if necessary, Saturday. All games are at 7 p.m.

Regina advanced to Round 2 by sweeping the visiting UBC Thunderbirds in a quarter-final. The Cougars won 85-70 on Friday and 71-62 on Saturday.

Kyanna Giles led the Cougars with 20 points, seven assists and six rebounds in the opener before scoring a career-high 28 points Saturday, when she added six rebounds. Charlotte Kot, who had 19 points for the Cougars on Friday, had 12 points and nine rebounds in Game 2.

• The U of R’s men’s basketball team’s season ended Friday with a 105-98 overtime loss to the host University of Lethbridge Pronghorns.

Lethbridge, which won 115-68 on Friday, swept a best-of-three quarter-final.

Alex Igual led the Cougars with 27 points on Saturday. Lethbridge’s Zac Overwater had 43 points and 16 rebounds.

• The Cougars women’s hockey team was swept by the host University of Alberta Pandas in a best-of-three quarter-final.

Jaycee Magwood scored for the U of R in Friday’s opener. Sam Geekie scored for Regina on Saturday.

 

]]> http://leaderpost.com/sports/local-sports/cougars-advance-to-canada-west-semi-final/feed/ 0 021718-180216_WBB__ART4811 legacycontent GALLERY: All-Star Celebrity Classic http://leaderpost.com/sports/hockey/gallery-all-star-celebrity-classic http://leaderpost.com/sports/hockey/gallery-all-star-celebrity-classic#respond Sun, 18 Feb 2018 03:05:07 +0000 http://leaderpost.com/?p=361089 Hockey legends took to the ice at the Brandt Centre Saturday to play in the All-Star Celebrity Classic game.

The atmosphere was jovial as former pros cracked jokes and told stories between shifts.

While many of the players were moving a little slower than they did during their careers, their finesse and knowledge of the game was on full display.

Leader-Post photojournalist Brandon Harder documented the event.

 

Hockey legend Wendel Clark (#17) comes out of the tunnel.

 

Members of Team WHL line up along the blue line.

 

Members of Team Sask line up along the blue line. Curtis Leschyshyn can be seen on the right.

 

Netminder Ed Staniowski gets twisted around.

 

Robyn Regehr carries the puck.

 

Kelly Chase, left, chats with Brian Skrudland, centre, and Mike Keane on the bench.

 

Rob Brown recovers from a spill.

 

Brian Propp, right, holds up Travis Moen.

 

Tim Cheveldae gloves a shot.

 

Players hang out in the dressing room during intermission.

 

Netminder Ed Staniowski takes a break in the dressing room.

 

Dave Babych jokes with teammates before returning to the bench after an intermission.

 

A fan holds a note made out to Wendel Clark.

 

Wendel Clark carries the puck.

 

Mike Sillinger returns to the bench after a shift.

 

Kelly Chase, right, was hollering at team mates and cracking jokes on the bench. He can be seen here between plays.

 

Curtis Leschyshyn, left, carries the puck around the net while being pursued by Rob Niedermayer.

 

Goaltender Shaun Fleming gets lucky as a shot flies just over the crossbar behind him.

]]> http://leaderpost.com/sports/hockey/gallery-all-star-celebrity-classic/feed/ 0 All-Star Classic, Regina, 17 Feb 2018 (2 of 4) brandonharder Pats get some redemption in Moose Jaw http://leaderpost.com/sports/hockey/regina-pats/pats-get-some-redemption-in-moose-jaw http://leaderpost.com/sports/hockey/regina-pats/pats-get-some-redemption-in-moose-jaw#respond Sat, 17 Feb 2018 05:49:37 +0000 http://leaderpost.com/?p=338514 MOOSE JAW — Turnabout was fair play for the Regina Pats.

Tied 2-2 after 40 minutes, Regina erupted with three goals in a span 3:35 and went on to beat the Moose Jaw Warriors for the first time this season, prevailing 5-3 before a sellout crowd of 4,613 at Mosaic Place.

It was Regina’s second of three straight games against the league-leading Warriors (43-10-1-2), who won the opener on Wednesday night at the Brandt Centre. In that contest, Moose Jaw scored three times in just 43 seconds and hung on for a 6-3 win.

Two days later, the tables turned.

“We played hard from start to finish,” said Pats head coach/GM John Paddock. “We played right from start to finish. When you do that you have a chance to get rewarded. When you’re playing against a team like them, you have to do that or you’re not going to win.”

The Pats learned that lesson the hard way, losing their first five meetings with Moose Jaw this season. That streak came to an end Friday, much to the relief of the visitors.

“We know we can compete with these guys,” said Pats defenceman Josh Mahura. “I don’t think there was much of a mental thing for us (to overcome). As much as it might not look like it from the outside, we’re a confident team in our dressing room. If we stick to our game plan we feel we can battle with all the (top) teams in this league. We had a pretty good game tonight and kind of created our own chances by forechecking hard and causing some turnovers.

“It was just nice to come out with the win against these guys.”

Now the focus shifts to Sunday’s rubber match at the Brandt Centre, where Moose Jaw has already won three times this season.

That said, Warriors head coach Tim Hunter was far from pleased with his team’s effort in the last visit on Wednesday — minus a three-goal, 43-second barrage, of course.

He offered a similar appraisal on Friday.

“We played the same,” he said after being outshot 36-28. “Nothing has changed.”

Except the end result.

“It was kind of a vicious cycle,” continued Hunter, who plans to “appeal to our team to get prepared for their pressure. When you’re prepared for pressure, you beat pressure and you catch them in between. But we were unwilling to do that.”

They knew it, too.

“(The Pats) came out here and outworked us tonight and they wanted it more,” said veteran forward Tanner Jeannot. “They played a hard game with lots of pressure and we just weren’t ready for it. We’re going to be putting that into our game plan going into Sunday and we’re going to come out with a better effort.”

The Pats outshot Moose Jaw 13-7 in the first period but found themselves down 1-0 on a goal by Jayden Halbgewachs.

Although Moose Jaw’s Brody Willms was the busier of the two netminders in the opening 20 minutes, Max Paddock made an early statement with two brilliant saves — both on Jeannot.

“He came up big at the right time,” said John Paddock.

Nick Henry put Regina on the board with a power-play goal 36 seconds into the second period and Jesse Gabrielle made it 2-1 midway through the frame. Moose Jaw’s Vince Loschiavo responded on the man advantage with five seconds on the clock to tie it 2-2 after 40 minutes.

The momentum abruptly swung back to Regina 3:59 into the third period when Emil Oksanen scored a power-play goal. That was followed by two goals 1:22 apart from Mahura, who beat Willms both times from long distance.

“I didn’t really know if I was going to score or not,” Mahura said of his first marker, which came from the left half-wall while using the D-man as a screen. “I thought, ‘Just get the puck on net.’ It went in.”

Then it happened again.

After Mahura made it 5-2, Moose Jaw’s Justin Almeida rounded out the scoring in garbage time when his shot went in off defenceman Liam Schioler. Just 11 seconds later, the Pats were celebrating a meaningful victory but also mindful that a rematch is on the horizon.

“Obviously they’re going to come out real hard on Sunday,” Mahura said of the Warriors. “We’re going to come with the same mentality we did tonight and give a little more and hopefully come out with the same result.”

EXTRAS: Regina (30-24-5-1) moved out of the top wildcard playoff spot and into third place in the East Division, one point ahead of the Brandon Wheat Kings. Brandon still has three games in hand … Pats C Koby Morrisseau played his first game since the sudden passing of his father on Jan. 12 … Regina was without No. 1 goalie Ryan Kubic, who may be suffering from a concussion. He has missed four straight games … The Warriors were missing 100-point man Brayden Burke due to injury. Hunter said he was a last-minute scratch and is day-to-day.

gharder@postmedia.com

]]> http://leaderpost.com/sports/hockey/regina-pats/pats-get-some-redemption-in-moose-jaw/feed/ 0 021618-Pats_V_Warriors_20180214_10.JPG gregharderlp Bronson Gordon claims Crown witnesses lied during Reno Lee murder trial http://leaderpost.com/news/crime/bronson-gordon-claims-crown-witnesses-lied-during-reno-lee-murder-trial Sat, 17 Feb 2018 00:54:14 +0000 http://leaderpost.com/?p=360817 Bronson Gordon told a Regina jury Crown witnesses lied about his alleged involvement in the confinement and killing of Reno Lee.

“He’s lying, he’s really lying,” Gordon said of one witness who testified Gordon armed him with a gun to confront and confine Lee.

He also said a woman lied in saying Gordon told her she had to do some favours for them and a second woman wasn’t telling the truth when she testified about telling Gordon of blood found in her house.

But Gordon admitted to having lied numerous times himself in the course of two videotaped statements he provided to police the month after Lee’s death.

Gordon began his testimony on Wednesday with questions from his lawyer Marianna Jasper before facing cross-examination Thursday and Friday by the Crown and lawyers representing his two co-accused, Andrew Bellegarde and Daniel Theodore.

Gordon, 33, Bellegarde, 24, and Theodore, 34, are standing trial on charges of first-degree murder and offering an indignity to human remains. The charges relate to a string of events from April 16, 2015, the date 34-year-old Lee was allegedly killed.

The three men accused of killing, dismembering and decapitating Reno Lee in 2015. From left, Andrew Michael Bellegarde, Bronson Chad Gordon and Daniel Theodore. REGINA LEADER-POST

During the Crown’s case, the jury heard testimony Lee was held at gunpoint at Gordon’s Angus Street apartment before being taken to a house on Garnet Street where he was bound and eventually shot twice in the head. Court heard his dismembered and decapitated body was found later that month in a shallow grave on the edge of the Star Blanket First Nation.

Gordon’s role in the night’s events has been the subject of his testimony, which entered the third day with an often-intense cross-examination by co-Crown prosecutor Adam Breker.

Gordon has maintained he knew nothing about what was to transpire that night, telling the jury his intention in meeting with Lee was for the two drug dealers to talk business.

Reno Lee.

But Breker suggested Gordon was well aware there was to be more to that meeting than discussions about drugs. Breker pointed to previous testimony from Gordon that he’d been confronted over his own drug debt by a “Mexican” identified only as Romeo, who threatened Gordon. Gordon said Theodore — often referred to by the name Buddha — was brought on board to manage that debt.

Breker suggested to Gordon his experience with Romeo meant he knew far more about the fate awaiting Lee than he was letting on, pointing to portions of Gordon’s videotaped police statements from May 15 and 16, 2015 in which he said what happened to the heavily indebted Lee “was supposed to happen to me.”

Gordon told the court he lied during those interviews, claimed police coached him on what to say and said he was high on crystal meth.

Breker also questioned Gordon about the believability of his testimony on various points, such as Gordon saying he was angry his good friend was dragged into the incident when his house was used to confine and eventually kill Lee. Breker questioned Gordon why, if he was so angry, he would have sent free drugs over to some of those involved in the confinement.

“It doesn’t make sense …,” Gordon agreed. “Everything makes no sense what happened there that night.”

As to why Gordon didn’t confront Theodore over what happened, Gordon replied, “I’m scared of Buddha.”

Breker pointed out that if Gordon’s version of events is to be believed, the night was just a “series of bad coincidences” for him or “bad luck” that Lee, initially confined at Gordon’s apartment, ended up taped up and ultimately dead in the home of Gordon’s friend.

“It’s not bad luck,” Gordon said. “It’s devastating, not only to my life but to other people’s lives that went there.”

Lawyers for Bellegarde and Theodore said evidence is not being called in their clients’ cases.

The jury returns on Wednesday for closing addresses by counsel.

hpolischuk@postmedia.com

twitter.com/LPHeatherP

]]> 011718-court011718-2.JPG hpolischuk Time will tell if Riders dive into free agency will pay off http://leaderpost.com/sports/football/cfl/saskatchewan-roughriders/time-will-tell-if-riders-dive-into-free-agency-pays-dividends http://leaderpost.com/sports/football/cfl/saskatchewan-roughriders/time-will-tell-if-riders-dive-into-free-agency-pays-dividends#respond Sat, 17 Feb 2018 00:20:58 +0000 http://leaderpost.com/?p=360872 John Murphy was cautious when asked whether the Saskatchewan Roughriders are an improved team now that the CFL’s free-agent frenzy has cooled down.

“Until we put on the pads, that’s a tough question to answer,’’ the Riders’ vice-president of football operations and player personnel responded Friday from his home in New Orleans.

“Does it look better on paper? Being good on paper has never won anything. I don’t want to be disrespectful to the hard work those players put in last year. They helped turn the corner and put this team back on the track of being a playoff-contending club.

“On paper, in certain areas that we needed to fortify and to get better, we’re better.’’

The Riders addressed many of their needs prior to the deadline by re-signing veterans such as receiver Duron Carter, defensive end Willie Jefferson, quarterback Brandon Bridge and centre Dan Clark, and trading for defensive end Charleston Hughes and quarterback Zach Collaros.

Once free agency started Tuesday, the Riders landed defensive tackle Zack Evans, linebacker Sam Hurl, running back Jerome Messam and offensive lineman Travis Bond in addition to re-signing fullback Spencer Moore.

The Riders also cut offensive lineman Derek Dennis, linebacker Glenn Love and middle linebacker Henoc Muamba to clear salary-cap space.

Murphy said it was difficult to release the aforementioned veterans, who had contributed so much in 2017.

“For us to stay competitive and take the next step by doing what it takes to host a playoff game or to play a road playoff game like the one we encountered last year, we’re much better equipped to handle it than if we had stayed the same,’’ he said.

Muamba was reportedly due a $35,000 roster bonus Thursday and, with bonuses, could have earned as much as $220,000 in 2018. The Riders cut Muamba after being unable to renegotiate his contract.

“They were looking for a high-value contract, which is fair for them to expect,’’ Murphy said. “That would have left us without the ability to sign or even compete to sign a defensive tackle or other guys who were free agents. It was a good class of Canadian defensive tackles this year, but each one of those guys got deals that were better than the ones they had.’’

Murphy feels the Riders may have more flexibility at middle linebacker without Muamba. Hurl started 18 games at middle linebacker in 2017 with the Winnipeg Blue Bombers and can play also play weak-side linebacker.

“We were able to make the moves we made by adding a substantial Canadian defensive tackle and a steady linebacker who can rotate and compete at (middle or weak-side linebacker),’’ Murphy said. “We also have the guys that we have drafted over the years.

“The combination of being able to come out of the day with multiple Canadian options to compete in spots allows us be in a much better position if there is an injury or if somebody isn’t as productive as you would expect him to be. This way, we’re not tied to a one-position player.’’

The Riders are still searching for a left offensive tackle, boundary cornerback and another Canadian defensive tackle.

“It’s about fitting in with who we want competing at the spot and how they fit in monetarily with what we’ve put together,’’ Murphy said. “We’re probably on the sixth or seventh version of the projection of what the roster with the salary cap would look like. That’s the clock we’re talking about.’’

NOTES: The Riders announced on Friday the signings of three nationals — running back Johnny Augustin, defensive back Adam Laurensse and defensive lineman Cory Robinson … Dennis signed Friday with the Calgary Stampeders, with whom he was named the CFL’s lineman of the year in 2016.

mmccormick@postmedia.com

twitter.com/murraylp

]]> http://leaderpost.com/sports/football/cfl/saskatchewan-roughriders/time-will-tell-if-riders-dive-into-free-agency-pays-dividends/feed/ 0 John Murphy murraymccormickleaderpost Creator of Master Keys to Success unsuccessful in fraud appeal http://leaderpost.com/news/crime/creator-of-master-keys-to-success-unsuccessful-in-fraud-appeal http://leaderpost.com/news/crime/creator-of-master-keys-to-success-unsuccessful-in-fraud-appeal#respond Fri, 16 Feb 2018 23:43:47 +0000 http://leaderpost.com/?p=360890 Despite insisting he’s a “humanitarian” and not a criminal, the creator of Master Keys to Success lost an appeal of his convictions for fraud and money laundering.

“I can’t see a thing I would have done different,” Steven Vincent Weeres told the Saskatchewan Court of Appeal during arguments on Friday.

He later added his only intention was to help people — but his plans for a computer training program have instead cost him years behind bars and his victims hundreds of thousands of dollars. “I did it out of love of humanity,” he said.

The Regina judge who convicted him more than two years ago concluded he acted out of greed and an intention to help himself to other people’s money. An appeal court likewise found no reason to overturn her verdict.

“We can find no merit to the grounds of your appeal. In our view the trial judge did not commit any factual or legal error,” Justice Jacelyn Ryan-Froslie said in a decision made unanimous by Justices Ralph Ottenbreit and Maurice Herauf.

Their decision marks the end of a long legal road for Weeres, now 59, stretching back nearly two decades when he first got in trouble with securities regulators. Appearing via video link from a conference room at a B.C. prison, Weeres upon hearing the decision closed the book on his pages of notes, picked up his pens, and readied himself to return to his room at William Head Institution.

He was sentenced in October 2015 to five years in prison for fraud and money laundering — less 505 days’ credit for pre-trial custody served when he skipped bail. He must also serve two more years if he fails to pay a $200,000 fine in lieu of forfeiting the money he laundered. He’s also been ordered to pay $482,690 in victim restitution.

Weeres created an interactive, training software program called Master Keys to Success. During his seven-week-long trial, at which he represented himself without a lawyer, Saskatchewan residents testified they put thousands of dollars into the business venture, with promises of doubling their money. But Justice Janet McMurtry found Weeres misappropriated some $650,000 to $800,000 of that money, spending it on vacations, rent for a beachfront home on Vancouver Island, dining, drinking and gambling.

Most of his appeal arguments laid blame on sales people involved with Master Keys. “I had no idea what representations were being made,” said Weeres, who also blamed the judge for bias and not helping him sufficiently to present his case. 

But Crown prosecutor Erin Bartsch said an appeal court is to look for legal error — not give Weeres a shot at re-trying his case. She also repeatedly pointed to examples in the trial transcript of McMurtry trying to help the self-represented accused.

“The appellant was accommodated every step of the way,” she said. And the appeal court agreed.

Weeres was originally granted parole seven months into his sentence, but it was revoked last year after the board found he was hatching new investment schemes while at a half-way house.

When he began his submissions Friday, Weeres argued every day he’s behind bars is costing him $26,900 because he isn’t making good on a multimillion-dollar project to manufacture log houses for Papua New Guinea and U.S. veterans.

“What I’m trying to do is right for society,” he said. “Society has been punished enough.”

bpacholik@postmedia.com

]]> http://leaderpost.com/news/crime/creator-of-master-keys-to-success-unsuccessful-in-fraud-appeal/feed/ 0 110215-Weeres10092015-06.JPG-1103_weeres_appeal-W.jpg bpacholik Callander looking forward to banner weekend with Pats http://leaderpost.com/sports/hockey/regina-pats/callander-looking-forward-to-banner-weekend-with-pats http://leaderpost.com/sports/hockey/regina-pats/callander-looking-forward-to-banner-weekend-with-pats#respond Fri, 16 Feb 2018 23:37:15 +0000 http://leaderpost.com/?p=350083 Jock Callander’s latest honour won’t wrap around his finger but it will hang nicely from the rafters of the Brandt Centre.

The Regina Pats’ legend will have his No. 15 jersey retired by the club prior to Sunday’s WHL game against the Moose Jaw Warriors (2 p.m., Brandt Centre).

The pre-game ceremony is part of a jam-packed Homecoming Weekend, which begins the 100-day countdown toward the 100th Memorial Cup in Regina.

The festivities commenced Friday with the Pats Community Foundation Honours Dinner, followed on Saturday by the All-Star Celebrity Classic alumni game (3 p.m., Brandt Centre).

Callander is one of 40 former NHL players slated to participate, marking his first official game at the Brandt Centre (formerly the Agridome) since the 1982 WHL final against the Portland Winterhawks.

“I was coming back for the alumni game and was excited about that,” said Callander, 56, a Regina product who now resides in Cleveland. “Then they called me a couple weeks ago (about the jersey retirement). It wasn’t expecting it. It’s a big honour.”

It’s not the first time Callander has been recognized in such a manner. His number was previously retired by the IHL’s Cleveland/Muskegon Lumberjacks, with whom he spent 15 of his 18 pro seasons — many of them alongside former Pats teammate Dave Michayluk.

Callander retired in 2000 as the IHL’s all-time leader with 1,402 points (regular season and playoffs). He also won a pair of Turner Cup titles (1986 and ’89), receiving two of his six career championships rings. The first was in 1980 when he helped the Pats to a WHL title. Each of the last two came in 2016 from the AHL’s Cleveland Monsters and NBA’s Cleveland Cavaliers while serving in an administrative role.

“It was a pretty exciting summer,” he said.

Callander is technically employed by the Cavaliers, who own the Monsters as well as the Arena Football League’s Cleveland Gladiators and the NBA G League’s Canton Charge. He does some work with the other affiliate teams but spends most of his time with the Monsters, serving as their senior director of hockey affairs and team services.

Callander wears a number of hats, including some community relations work and organizing team travel. He’s also a liaison between the Monsters and league as well as their parent club, the NHL’s Columbus Blue Jackets.

Callander previously served as an assistant coach in the AHL and IHL, which merged in 2001.

As a player, Callander appeared in 131 NHL games, mostly with the Pittsburgh Penguins. He won the Stanley Cup in 1992 after he was a late-season callup, dressing for 12 NHL playoff games en route to the title.

“I might be the only guy with an NBA championship ring and a Stanley Cup championship ring,” chuckled Callander, who has accumulated quite a collection of awards and accolades over the years. “I still have my old Western Hockey League ring from when we won the west. The rings were a lot smaller back then. Even to look at my Turner Cup rings (from the ’80s) compared to my Calder Cup ring … they just keep getting bigger and bigger.”

Callander played parts of four seasons with the Pats, recording 158 goals and 368 points (sixth in franchise history) despite playing in just 201 regular-season games. He wrapped up his junior career in 1981-82 by winning the Bob Clarke Trophy as the league’s top scorer, finishing with 79 goals and 190 points in 71 games.

“Jocko was an amazing player,” said Todd Strueby, who played with Callander in Regina and Muskegon. “He was one of the best puck-protection and puck-handling players I’ve ever seen. He was fantastic offensively and was always a great teammate.”

Callander has fond memories of playing for his home-town team.

His ties actually go back to his brother Drew, who helped the Pats win the 1974 Memorial Cup before working with club as an assistant coach and now as a scout.

“I remember going to Pats games with dad when it was at Exhibition Stadium,” added Callander. “Obviously I got to watch Drew play on that powerhouse team that won the Memorial Cup. I always wanted to be able to play with the Pats. We had such good teams those years. It was a lot of fun.”

gharder@postmedia.com

]]> http://leaderpost.com/sports/hockey/regina-pats/callander-looking-forward-to-banner-weekend-with-pats/feed/ 0 Callander gregharderlp A Regina grandpa made his grandchildren an amazing backyard hockey rink http://leaderpost.com/news/local-news/a-regina-grandpa-made-his-grandchildren-an-amazing-backyard-hockey-rink http://leaderpost.com/news/local-news/a-regina-grandpa-made-his-grandchildren-an-amazing-backyard-hockey-rink#respond Fri, 16 Feb 2018 23:32:16 +0000 http://leaderpost.com/?p=360998 It looks like someone zapped an NHL rink with a shrink ray. 

Randy Durovick, a former Swift Current Bronco goalie, built an impressive backyard rink for his grandchildren in the backyard of his daughter’s Regina home.  The rink has boards surrounding the ice, and is decorated with WHL and NHL jerseys. It also has lights to illuminate it at night. Durovick previously worked as a parks and recreation manager in small towns in Saskatchewan and Alberta, so he knows a  thing or two about hockey rinks. 

Randy Durovick’s grandchildren play hockey on his elaborate backyard hockey rink at his home.
